annotations.html: Using commerce as an example, we can see how changes in worldviews and values came about: as Piggot explains, "Prospectors and miners, traders and middlemen, the organization of shipments and caravans, concessions and treaties, the concept of alien peoples and customs in distant lands - all these are involved in the enlargement of social comprehension demanded by the technological step of entering ... a bronze age." These innovations particularly required that man's ever-present xenophobia be overcome, as it was by new values such as hospitality, protection, and safe passage. For example, Hayek refers to the early Greek custom of the xenos, the guest-friend, who was assured individual admission and protection within an alien territory. He believes that early trade was very much a matter of personal relations between individuals of different communities. As a consequence, the increased opportunities to deal with members of other communities helped break the "solidarity, common aims and collectivism of the original small groups."

annotations.html: Many of you will be familiar with the term pathogenesis. We use it quite often in the biomedical sciences to refer to the processes by which a disease develops, including the factors that contribute to its progression. The word comes from the Greek pathos ('suffering', 'disease') and genesis ('origin'). The lesser-known term 'salutogenesis' comes from the Latin salus ('health') and, again, the Greek genesis, and poses the question: how can we move towards greater health? Pathogenesis and salutogenesis are two sides of the same coin. Sadly, much of our modern-day medicine is focused on the pathogenic model: emphasis on all the scary illnesses and diseases that can await us if we don't take good care of ourselves (and sometimes even if we do). It is easier to conceptualise a disease state than a healthy state of an individual. We know that disease is caused by the presence of an insult that can be genetic, environmental, or caused by a decline in normal physiological function, such as during ageing. Health, on the other hand, seems to be more metaphysical - a so-called state of 'wellbeing'. As an absence of disease, health becomes somewhat passive.

This shows just how easily we can sometimes fool ourselves if we are not more careful in our reasoning.

annotations.html: Survivorship ① bias shows us that we can be fooled by the presence and existence of something if we fail to consider the wider ② context. The best known example is from World War II history, when British RAF planes returning from bombing runs in Germany were thought to be the most vulnerable in the areas where they were observed to be hit most often: around the wingtips, rear tail assemblies, and the center of the plane. But that was merely a ③ subset of all the planes sent out; the ones that had failed to return had been fatally hit in the more ④ trivial areas of the plane; the engines, cockpit, and fuel tanks. They didn't see those because they never returned. What survived to return was merely hit in less important areas and so to reinforce those areas-as was initially proposed-would have been a tragic error, merely protecting less important parts of the plane while leaving the vital parts exposed. This shows just how easily we can sometimes fool ourselves if we are not more careful in our ⑤ reasoning.

③ 대부분의 사람들은 온라인 광고를 무시하기 때문에 광고는 대체로 효과가 없다.
④ 오늘날 창의성에 가장 큰 위협이 되는 것은 전통 산업의 붕괴이다.
⑤ 온라인에서 콘텐츠를 공유하는 것은 주로 이타주의와 개방적 협업에 의해 이루어진다.
-- 해설: ②번은 주목 경제(attention economy)라는 개념과 광고 산업 및 알고리즘 기반 추천 시스템이 어떻게 우리의 주의를 수익화하는지에 대한 본문의 핵심 주장과 정확히 맞아떨어진다. 나머지 보기들은 본문의 논지와 관련성이 부족하거나 초점이 어긋나 있다.
